section.title: Installing standalone binary
section.para: Standalone binary versions are provided for PyPop that make minimal assumptions about external software installed on your system, and for the majority of users, will be the simplest way to install PyPop. We have only tested them on a subset of the possible operating systems and have noted them in the relevant section below.

section.title: Installing on GNU/Linux

formalpara.title: System requirements
formalpara.para: Your GNU/Linux system should contain at least 2.3.2 version of glibc (the GNU C library).

formalpara.title: Systems tested
formalpara.para: Red Hat Linux 9, Slackware 9.1 (may work on other platforms but untested at present)

listitem.para: Download the latest stable release and save it somewhere in your home directory:
From the command-line terminal untar and uncompress the package (typically using the GNU tar program):

section.para: At this point PyPop should be successfully installed. To test your installation, run the program and use the sample test files with the following steps:

listitem.para: Change directory into the extracted directory
Now you can run the interactive version of the program, by typing ./pypop.sh, at the command line.
PyPop will remember the names of the configuration and population files you used last, and will provide those as defaults in subsequent runs.

formalpara.title: Systems tested
formalpara.para: Windows 98, Windows XP (may work on other platform but untested at present)

listitem.para: Before starting an install on Windows, you must first make sure you have a copy of a zip file extractor such as PowerArchiver or WinZip.
Download the latest stable Windows release of PyPop and save it in one of your directories or on the Desktop:

Once you have downloaded the file, you should double-click it. If you have correctly installed one of the zip compression utilities, it should open using that zip program. Extract the contents of the zip file to your desktop, or wherever you normally save your programs and data. Consult the documentation for your archiving utility for details on how to do this (it should be reasonably self-explanatory).
Once you have the PyPopWin32-&VERSION; directory extracted, open the directory and double-click on the pypop.bat file.
A DOS shell should then open running the program inside it.

section.title: Installing from source
section.para: The source code for PyPop can be obtained here:

listitem.para: Simple Wrapper Interface Generator (SWIG): needs 'development' version 1.3.9 or 1.3.10. (Note: 1.3.11 or later will not work).

libxml2/libxslt including libxml2-python, a Python interface to the GNOME XML/XSLT parser (This is a fast C library-based parser. Most recent GNU/Linux distributions will ship libxml2/libxslt as standard, but you may need to obtain libxml2-python as a separate package).
(Untested recently: 4Suite a pure Python XML/XSLT parsing engine.)

section.title: Installation

para.emphasis: Before starting, you must ensure you have installed all the system requirements listed above. In particular, make sure Python and Distutils are installed correctly.

section.para: Unzip and untar the above tar ball. Build and install PyPop by changing into the PyPop-&VERSION; directory, and type:
section.screen: python setup.py build python setup.py install
section.para: If you need to do additional configuration (e.g. changing the base directory) please type python setup.py, or see the documentation for Distutils.
